description: From Middle English further, forther, from Old English forþor, furþor (“further”, adverb), from Proto-West Germanic *furþer, from Proto-Indo-European *per- (a common preposition), equivalent to fore + -ther (a vestigial comparative ending still present in such words as other, either, whether, and, in altered form, in after); or as sometimes stated, as forth +‎ -er. Cognate with Scots forder, furder, Saterland Frisian foarder, West Frisian fierder, Dutch verder, German fürder.

entries.meaning: (comparative form of far) More distant; relatively distant.
examples: See those two lampposts? Run to the further one.
He was standing at the further end of the corridor.
I have one further comment to make.

entries.meaning: (comparative form of far) To, at or over a greater distance in space, time or other extent.
examples: I can run further than you.
I live a little further out of town.
How was your company doing ten years further back?

entries.meaning: (comparative form of far) To a greater extent or degree.
examples: Of the two civilisations, this one was further advanced.
I do not propose to discuss it any further. - Please, let me explain just a little further.

entries.meaning: Beyond what is already stated or is already the case.
examples: Chapter 10 further explains the ideas introduced in Chapter 9.
Further, affiant sayeth naught. (A formal statement ending a deposition or affidavit, immediately preceding the affiant's signature.)
It is overlong, and further, it makes no sense.
Further to our recent telephone call, I am writing to clarify certain points raised.
This example is further to the one on page 17.

verbs.description: further (third-person singular simple present furthers, present participle furthering, simple past and past participle furthered)

examples: Upon this he brought me a cotton bag and giving it to me, said, "Take this bag and fill it with pebbles from the beach and go forth with a company of the townsfolk to whom I will give a charge respecting thee. Do as they do and belike thou shalt gain what may further thy return voyage to thy native land."

entries.meaning: (transitive) To encourage growth; to support progress or growth of something; to promote.
